content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It was fun to code and I love the way someone can do the rotation with an HV instead, some will notice this and it will help them. Overall, it was great and sufficiently described.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle with a neat trick that's visually satisfying to work out.
Also spent way too long trying to code golf in Python... not worth it.

i=input;p=print;s="*"*10
f=i();i();x=y=-1;z=0
while y<0:y=i().find("X")-1;x+=1
for c in f:z^=c!="R";y=[7-y,y][c=="V"];x=[4-x,x][c=="H"]
p(s)
for j in range(5):t=j==x;p(f'*{" "*y*t+"XO"[z]*t+" "*(8-t-y*t)}*')
p(s)
Looks cool, i'd like to play something like this in clash
It would be better if the rotation happened only from right to left or from left to right, but I liked it.

✅ Approved the contribution.
I would love to see this while playing CoC. I wonder if anyone else will think of mirroring it like I did or replacing 'R' with 'HV'.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
Oh wow. This was the first problem I am reviewing. This was so much fun to implement. I really enjoyed it. My only problem would be it takes a bit of time to figure it out.

If you'd like to test Reverse mode (if you read this comment before reading the description), here's a Python Reverse mode emulator:

https://ato.pxeger.com/run?1=tVQ9T8MwEJUYkOpfcaRDEyQWGApITBBkBghy08gLqqrWbSPRJMqHgN_C0gX-E_012K7VOFLaJm3jyed39_yeL7nv3-grnYXBYnl61QZiezbp2fDsPNjg2j0XteHp5bXvglwtp-_ygB9iWK_W-XpxIA84oDIcCVAVaQBIAJoBNqnaZMmrY6lwHW3GknOwJbK3JV0H3dNSpYbXtYTzNh1gSQG0siXa5IeHCSaHWXJ2e90G0GNbIh7GHjlSl6oBVAfo8bskDHFbpIolp9HBVgLQbZZEP7IA0hmDLGFxJ4HOfThmHQiy-SBlSZpA6s9ZAuEqyQ-ijJ-ZYi9hq4Xy1DvoohEv5xvDMH6ydHJx_ffWhsd3P5Ll0XDKzhCa8FhkSzbTQpMwBp9HEA-DKTO71i0SyuPwQ0tCUewHqWmI4oiNJZdhqUsu-X2SRggZaFxrcYqTfbKRKTSqysXy5AYj7Xny0YS019y9zRm8Ap3KoHvTkTK6zYXl8nMGXCpPptOyyp1uxYSqJ1G-xzbHckLU5aQlp5pt9YvWV1rY0gLr6hP6Bw

It shows just the test cases in the header, and then repeats whatever code you type on the 7 tests. I can't think of a good way to verify whether you get the answers right, but the answers are in the header (like Reverse mode).

This is definitely on the complicated side of Clashes I've seen. It's cool, but feels like it would be a lot of rules to pick up on, especially in "Reverse" mode. I definitely appreciate having X/O (2 symbols) instead of b/p/q/d (4), but maybe flipping the symbol at all is still more complexity than might be best for a Clash? Just a question I thought I'd float for input. I don't have experience balancing Clashes.

Flip? I just thought of it like mirroring the page across its centre line.
R? I replaced it with 'HV' since a 180° rotation is the same as doing a horizontal flip and then a vertical flip. It might take a bit more processing, but it made sense to me.
Honestly, high school geometry helped a lot here —  just thinking of it like mirroring over axes.
Great work!

Thanks, I'm glad you liked it.

It's true you can think of it as mirroring + changing the symbol, but it's meant to represent a flip of the page (with the new symbol indicating that things on the frontside are now on the backside of the page).

All the flips are essentially 180° rotations about three orthogonal axes (horizontal, vertical and 'normal' = out of the page). The rotation about the normal axis doesn't feel like a flip since the page rotates within the plane of its surface, though. :) And yeah, you can replace R with HV as you discovered!
On the other hand, having a more complex input (allowing the page to be marked with either an O or an X in the input stage) could make the flip rule more immediately obvious in Reverse mode.

I appreciate your feedback. I'm open to removing Reverse mode if it does seem too hard, but it would be good to see what others think. I can't say without bias whether I would see the trick in Reverse, but I like to think the first two tests would make it clear with "H" and "V" being horizontal and vertical flips.

I think you do have enough/suitable test cases to communicate both tricks. I think testing for Reverse mode (if that can be done) would be good... you have 2 tricks to pick up on as well as a puzzle that takes slightly longer to code/debug. I think this puzzle took me at least 3x longer than the average Clash, not done in reverse mode (didn't time myself... should have).

This is the best I could do for a Python reverse test:

https://ato.pxeger.com/run?1=tVQ9T8MwEJUYkOpfcaRDEyQWGApITBBkBghy08gLqqrWbSPRJMqHgN_C0gX-E_012K7VOFLaJm3jyed39_yeL7nv3-grnYXBYnl61QZiezbp2fDsPNjg2j0XteHp5bXvglwtp-_ygB9iWK_W-XpxIA84oDIcCVAVaQBIAJoBNqnaZMmrY6lwHW3GknOwJbK3JV0H3dNSpYbXtYTzNh1gSQG0siXa5IeHCSaHWXJ2e90G0GNbIh7GHjlSl6oBVAfo8bskDHFbpIolp9HBVgLQbZZEP7IA0hmDLGFxJ4HOfThmHQiy-SBlSZpA6s9ZAuEqyQ-ijJ-ZYi9hq4Xy1DvoohEv5xvDMH6ydHJx_ffWhsd3P5Ll0XDKzhCa8FhkSzbTQpMwBp9HEA-DKTO71i0SyuPwQ0tCUewHqWmI4oiNJZdhqUsu-X2SRggZaFxrcYqTfbKRKTSqysXy5AYj7Xny0YS019y9zRm8Ap3KoHvTkTK6zYXl8nMGXCpPptOyyp1uxYSqJ1G-xzbHckLU5aQlp5pt9YvWV1rY0gLr6hP6Bw

It shows just the test cases in the header, and then repeats whatever code you type on the 7 tests. I can't think of a good way to verify whether you get the answers right, but the answers are in the header (like Reverse mode).

Flipping "X" to become "O" feels like a compromise on simplicity, I suppose? A more realistic representation might be to start with "b": it becomes "d" when flipped horizontally, "p" when flipped vertically, and "q" when rotated 180°.

I thought about something like that too, but I quite liked this level of simplicity.

Also, the logic for X and O is that it's a common conventional in physics (esp. for magnetic fields). The "X" is meant to represent the rear-view of an archer's arrow and the "O" is the front view.

https://img.crackap.com/ap/physics-c/a5/Image00884.jpg
